types.html:
mademoiselle f (plural mesdemoiselles)

  1. (dated) Miss; A form of address or title for an unmarried woman
  2. Miss; A form of address or title for a young woman, regardless of marital status
    1. (Quebec) Miss; as a form of address or title for a young girl

Usage notes

[edit]
  • Mademoiselle has been on the decline as a title for unmarried women since the 1970s, and its usage is restricted to addressing young women if their age is to be highlighted. In Quebec, this usage is restricted even further, only being used for young girls or women who want to be referred by it.[1] Madame is used and preferred to refer to women regardless of marital status.
  • After being regarded as sexist, mademoiselle has been banned or discouraged in official documents in the following French-speaking regions:
    • Switzerland since 1973
    • Quebec since 1976[2]
    • The French Community of Belgium since December 13, 1993[3]
    • France since February 21, 2012[4][5]
    • Luxembourg since March 9, 2012[6]
  • The form madelle (a blend of madame and mademoiselle) has been suggested as a replacement, but never caught on. Instead, madame is used regardless of marital status.

Synonyms

[edit]
  • Mlle
  • Mlle.

Derived terms

[edit]
  • croque-mademoiselle

Descendants

[edit]
  • → Alemannic German: Màmsel, Màmselala
  • → English: mademoiselle, → mamzelle (from mamzelle)
  • → German: Mamsell (from mamzelle)
  • → Russian: мадемуазель (mademuazelʹ)
  • → Turkish: matmazel
  • → Persian: مادمازل (mâdmâzel)
trans: A form of address or title for an unmarried woman
A form of address or title for a young woman, regardless of marital status
A form of address or title for an unmarried woman
A form of address or title for a young woman, regardless of marital status

title: mademoiselle
